noun

character
  1. A letter of the Old Church Slavonic alphabet, called вѣдѣ (vědě), and written in the Old Cyrillic script.

column2:
noun
  1. thing, matter, object
  2. nature, essence
  3. material good, property, possession

verb
  1. (transitive, intransitive) to see
  2. (transitive, intransitive) to look, behold
  3. (intransitive) to understand, contemplate

verb
  1. to dwell, live
  2. (for birds) to wraps its nest

noun
  1. a Roman, a speaker of a Romance language
  2. a Vlach

noun
  1. undulation, swell (series of surface waves in a body of water)
  2. (by extension) commotion, turmoil, agitation

noun
  1. wiseman, sage
  2. wizard, sorcerer, mage
  3. fortune teller, clairvoyant, magician
  4. (paganism) a priest

adj
  1. eternal
  2. age-old, existing since always
  3. permanent, lasting, perpetual, existing until always

character
  1. A letter of the Old Church Slavonic alphabet, called глаголи (glagoli), and written in the Old Cyrillic script.

verb
  1. to sound
  2. to say, to read
  3. to be worded, say

verb
  1. establish, build, create
  2. stabilize, fortify
  3. affirm, strengthen someone's beliefs
  4. restore, heal
  5. (refl) strengthened, became strong, established

verb
  1. grow stiff or useless
  2. become torpid
  3. become listless or inactive
  4. become dull

  7. promise, vow
  8. name, appellation

  13. reason, cause

  18. (semantic loan from Hebrew) thing, matter

verb

  2. to express in words, to utter

noun

  12. (figuratively) the bread of the eucharist

  1. A letter of the Old Church Slavonic alphabet, called дѥрв (djerv) or ꙉерьвь (đerĭvĭ), and written in the Old Cyrillic script.

character
  1. Monocular O, a variant of О (O) used in some manuscripts in word ꙩко (oko, “eye”) and its derivatives, and also in some other functions.

character
  1. Binocular O, a variant of О (O) used in some manuscripts in the dual or plural forms of the word око (oko, “eye”) (ꙫчи (oči, “eyes”)) and derivative words.

character
  1. Dual monocular O, a variant of О (O) used in some manuscripts in the dual or plural forms of the word око (oko, “eye”) (ꙭчи (oči, “eyes”)) and derivative words.

character
  1. Multiocular O, a variant of О (O) used in a single 15th-century manuscript in the phrase серафими многоꙮчитїй (serafimi mnogoočitij, “many-eyed seraphim”).
